content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays several fragments of fibro-adipose tissue. I can identify at least two large, discrete tissue pieces. The structure on the left appears to be a lymph node, characterized by its relatively well-circumscribed, nodular shape and basophilic/eosinophilic mottling, embedded within adipose tissue. The other tissue fragments also contain adipose tissue, blood vessels, and possibly other lymph nodes or tumor deposits that require examination. The overall impression is that this is a sample from a lymph node dissection for staging a colorectal cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, I would zoom into this area because it represents a potential lymph node. It has a distinct nodular architecture separate from the surrounding fat. The primary task in examining this specimen is to identify all lymph nodes and assess them for metastatic tumor. This specific nodule, located centrally in the largest tissue fragment on the left, is a prime candidate for a lymph node that needs to be evaluated at high magnification to confirm its nature and to search for any evidence of cancer cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is part of a structure identified as a potential lymph node in the lower-left tissue fragment. At low power, this specific region is conspicuously pale, eosinophilic, and paucicellular (containing few cells) compared to the expected dense, basophilic appearance of normal lymphoid tissue. This appearance is highly suspicious for a metastatic deposit, which can present as acellular mucin pools or elicit a desmoplastic stromal response. Therefore, high-magnification examination is necessary to look for atypical epithelial cells and confirm or rule out metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I have zoomed into the structure in the lower-left fragment because it has the classic appearance of a lymph node. The primary task for lymph node sections in a cancer case is to meticulously search for any evidence of metastasis. I am focusing on the periphery of the node, near the capsule and subcapsular sinus, as this is a common location for the initial spread of tumor cells. The area also shows some textural and color variation, with dense pink (eosinophilic) areas that require high-power examination to differentiate between fibrosis, hyalinization, or mucin pools associated with metastatic adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary goal with this specimen is to identify every lymph node and examine it for metastatic cancer. The area indicated by the green box is on a nodular structure embedded within the adipose tissue, which is a prime candidate for being a lymph node. I would systematically scan the entire slide and zoom into every such potential lymph node. This specific area, even at low power, has an unusual pale, acellular-looking quality that draws attention and requires high-magnification inspection to determine its nature. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task in this specimen is to identify all lymph nodes and assess them for metastasis. The area highlighted by the green box is a discrete, somewhat ill-defined nodule within the adipose tissue in the upper-left fragment. Any nodular structure in the pericolic fat must be scrutinized at high power to determine if it is a lymph node (and if it contains tumor) or a discontinuous tumor deposit. Therefore, I am zooming in to characterize this specific nodule. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is located within what I identified as a lymph node from the low-power view. At this magnification, this specific region shows an abnormal appearance. It lacks the typical uniform dark purple appearance of a normal lymph node and instead has a pale, smudgy, and somewhat basophilic look. This heterogeneity is highly suspicious for either metastatic tumor, particularly a mucinous type, or a treatment-related change like acellular mucin pools, which are crucial to identify for accurate staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because the structure within the green box is distinct from the surrounding adipose tissue. It appears more organized and cellular, suggesting it could be a lymph node that needs to be evaluated for metastatic disease. Alternatively, it could be a section of the primary tumor showing its relationship with the adjacent fat, which is crucial for determining the T stage (depth of invasion). Differentiating between a lymph node and the primary tumor, and assessing for malignancy in either, is a primary goal of this examination. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because there is an unusual, elongated, duct-like or cystic structure that is not a typical component of perirectal fat. In the context of a colorectal cancer workup, any epithelial structure outside of the main tumor must be carefully evaluated to rule out metastatic carcinoma, particularly lymphovascular invasion or a metastatic deposit. This structure's distinct, dark lining makes it a mandatory area for high-power examination to determine its nature. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it shows features that are abnormal and highly suspicious in the context of colorectal cancer. The pale, basophilic, and acellular-looking material is characteristic of extracellular mucin. In a patient with colorectal adenocarcinoma, particularly one who has received neoadjuvant therapy, finding pools of mucin is a critical step. The purpose of zooming in is to confirm the presence of mucin and, most importantly, to meticulously search for any residual viable malignant epithelial cells within or at the periphery of these mucin pools. The presence or absence of tumor cells within mucin in a lymph node or as a tumor deposit determines the final staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because, on low power, it stands out from the surrounding adipose tissue. It has a distinct basophilic (bluish/purplish) and somewhat gray, washed-out appearance. This suggests the presence of either a dense cellular infiltrate or, more likely given the appearance, pools of extracellular mucin. In a colorectal cancer case, finding mucin pools within a lymph node or perirectal fat is highly suspicious for metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma. Therefore, this area requires high-power examination to confirm the presence of tumor cells (viable or necrotic) within the mucin. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see large, irregular pools of pale, acellular, eosinophilic material consistent with mucin. There are no definitive viable tumor cells visible within these mucin pools. The mucin is surrounded by and dissects through bands of pink, fibrous stroma. This histological pattern is highly characteristic of a lymph node metastasis from a mucinous adenocarcinoma that has undergone neoadjuvant therapy (chemotherapy and/or radiation). The treatment has destroyed the cancer cells, leaving behind only the mucin they produced. This finding, even without viable cells, is classified as a positive lymph node (evidence of treated metastasis).
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see extensive, large pools of pale, faintly basophilic, amorphous, acellular-appearing material. This is characteristic of extracellular mucin. Floating within these mucin pools are some delicate strands of eosinophilic fibrous stroma and a few scattered, small, and sometimes pyknotic (shrunken and dark) nuclei, which could represent residual tumor cells, inflammatory cells (muciphages), or fibroblasts. The overall impression is that of a metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma. The presence of large mucin pools in a lymph node, even with few or no viable tumor cells (which can be a result of neoadjuvant therapy), is considered evidence of metastasis. This lymph node would be classified as positive.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see extensive, pale, amorphous, and largely acellular material. This substance has the characteristic appearance of extracellular mucin. It is surrounded by dense, pink, fibrous connective tissue (stroma) and some adipose tissue at the bottom. While viable tumor cells are not clearly identifiable in this specific field, there are some wispy strands of stroma and a few inflammatory cells within the mucin. In the context of colorectal adenocarcinoma, the presence of acellular mucin pools within a lymph node is considered evidence of metastasis (a complete pathological response with residual mucin, or active metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma). Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node, showing metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see abundant acellular, eosinophilic, lamellated (layered) material consistent with keratin debris. Surrounding this keratin, there is a prominent inflammatory reaction, including foreign body-type multinucleated giant cells and some hemorrhage. There are no definitive viable malignant cells visible in this specific field. My impression is a foreign body giant cell reaction to keratin. In the context of a treated colorectal adenocarcinoma (post-neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy), this finding is highly suspicious for a treated metastatic deposit that has undergone squamous differentiation and subsequent necrosis, leaving behind only keratin debris. This would be classified as a treatment effect.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows mature adipose tissue infiltrated by large, irregular pools of pale, amorphous, and slightly basophilic material. This material is consistent with acellular mucin. There is a surrounding stromal and inflammatory reaction at the interface with the fat. I do not see definitive viable malignant epithelial cells floating in the mucin in this particular field, nor do I see residual lymph node architecture. My impression is that this represents a tumor deposit of mucinous adenocarcinoma in the pericolic fat. The absence of viable cells could be due to treatment effect (if the patient received neoadjuvant therapy) or simply sampling. This finding would be classified as a positive node/tumor deposit and would contribute to upstaging the tumor (pN+).
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see extensive pools of pale, amorphous, and slightly basophilic (light purple/grey) material. This is characteristic of acellular mucin. I do not see any viable, intact malignant epithelial cells or well-formed glands within this mucin. There is some surrounding fibrous tissue and a few scattered inflammatory cells. My impression is that this represents an acellular mucin pool, which is evidence of a treated metastasis from a colorectal adenocarcinoma, showing a complete pathological response in this area. It's critical to search the rest of the node for any residual viable tumor cells.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I can clearly identify a section of the colonic wall. At the top, there is colonic mucosa with surface hemorrhage. Directly beneath the mucosa, there are extensive, large pools of pale, basophilic, acellular-looking material. This is extracellular mucin. Within these mucin pools, there are some floating clusters of atypical epithelial cells. Below the mucin, there is mature adipose tissue. My impression is that this is a primary mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon, showing invasion at least into the submucosa. The key finding is the presence of large amounts of extracellular mucin, which defines this as a mucinous subtype.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a large, cystic or duct-like space lined by a stratified, non-ciliated, cuboidal to low columnar epithelium. The epithelial cells are uniform, with regular, oval nuclei and no significant atypia, mitotic activity, or necrosis. This morphology is not consistent with metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. Instead, it is suggestive of a benign epithelial inclusion. The differential diagnosis for such a finding, depending on patient gender and exact location, would include a mesothelial cyst or a mullerian remnant like endosalpingiosis. This is a benign finding and not a lymph node or metastasis.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image confirms the presence of extensive, large pools of acellular mucin. The mucin has a characteristic basophilic, fibrillary, and slightly granular appearance. Surrounding these mucin pools, there is a fibrotic and mild chronic inflammatory reaction, composed of fibroblasts and scattered lymphocytes. In this particular field of view, there are no definitive viable malignant tumor cells visible. This finding is highly suggestive of a treatment effect, likely representing complete or near-complete regression of a mucinous adenocarcinoma following neoadjuvant therapy. The entire specimen would need to be carefully examined to rule out any foci of residual carcinoma before rendering a final diagnosis of a complete pathological response.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, there are large, confluent pools of pale, basophilic, acellular material, which is characteristic of extracellular mucin. Within these mucin pools, there are faint outlines of degenerated, necrotic tumor cells, often referred to as 'ghost cells'. Surrounding these mucin pools is a fibrotic and inflammatory response. At the top of the image, there appears to be a rim of compressed lymphoid tissue, suggesting this process is occurring within a lymph node. My impression is that this is a metastatic deposit of mucinous adenocarcinoma in a lymph node. The lack of viable tumor cells and the presence of extensive acellular mucin are indicative of a significant treatment effect, likely from neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy. This lymph node would be classified as positive for metastasis.
